data.author: James Dacey
data.description: Political disputes threaten the United Kingdom’s status in Horizon Europe, the world’s largest transnational funding program.
data.source: Eos: Earth And Space Science News
data.title: U.K.-Based Geoscientists Trapped in European Funding Impasse

data.description: By analyzing the data from NASA's Transiting Exoplanet Survey Satellite (TESS), Turkish astronomers have detected 10 new pulsating variable stars, including five Delta Scuti variables. The finding is reported in a paper published August 25 on the arXiv pre-print server.
data.source: Phys.org - News And Articles On Science And Technology
data.title: Ten new pulsating variable stars discovered

data.description: Standard medical imaging readily detects most solid brain cancers, one third of which are gliomas. Unfortunately, two complex surgeries are often necessary. But now, researchers from Japan may have devised a way to perform the initial biopsy, lab tests, and subsequent tumor removal during one surgical procedure.
data.source: Phys.org - News And Articles On Science And Technology
data.title: Fluorescence patterns aid medical diagnostics

data.description: Two astronauts on board China's Tiangong space station successfully completed a six-hour spacewalk Friday, the national human spaceflight agency said.
data.source: Phys.org - News And Articles On Science And Technology
data.title: China's Shenzhou-14 astronauts carry out spacewalk

data.author: Maria Temming
data.description: Writing about math anxiety and maintaining a “growth mindset” can help soothe stress about the subject.
data.source: Science News For Students
data.title: Let’s learn about dealing with math anxiety

data.description: Canadian sport is in crisis. Reports of misconduct are making headlines with troubling regularity. Many sports federations under the purview of Sport Canada appear saturated with harassment, bullying and abuse.
data.source: Phys.org - News And Articles On Science And Technology
data.title: Addressing abuse in sport requires internal change, external investigators

data.description: Everyone knows that trees provide shade. What may be less obvious are their contributions to evaporative cooling. Think of tree roots drawing water from the ground and pumping it to their leaves, which effectively sweat H2O, cooling the air around them in the process.
data.source: Phys.org - News And Articles On Science And Technology
data.title: Researchers study how urban trees affect environment

data.description: Microcombs have widely differing application areas—they can help us discover planets outside our solar system as well as track diseases in our bodies. New research results at Chalmers University of Technology, Sweden, now give a deeper understanding of how the line width in the combs works, something that will, among other things, enable even more precise measurements in the future. And the discovery was made almost by coincidence.
data.source: Phys.org - News And Articles On Science And Technology
data.title: Understanding how line widths in microcombs will enable more precise measurements

data.description: If you are used to getting regular health checkups, you might be familiar with endoscopes. The endoscope is an imaging device consisting of a camera and a light guide attached to a long flexible tube. It is particularly useful for acquiring images of the inside of a human body. For example, stomach and colon endoscopy are widely used for the early detection and diagnosis of diseases such as ulcers and cancers.
data.source: Phys.org - News And Articles On Science And Technology
data.title: The invention of a flexible endoscope thinner than a needle

data.description: The native Australian rodent Pseudomys fumeus, named smoky mouse for its color, was already fighting off extinction when the 2019–20 bushfire season hit.
data.source: Phys.org - News And Articles On Science And Technology
data.title: Scientists release world-first DNA map of an endangered Australian mouse, and it will help to save it

data.description: Much like humans, plants, and bacteria, the single-celled parasite Toxoplasma gondii (T. gondii) uses calcium as a messenger to coordinate important cellular processes. But while the messenger is the same, the communication pathways that form around calcium differ significantly between organisms.
data.source: Phys.org - News And Articles On Science And Technology
data.title: Parasite researchers melt down proteins to understand their roles in infection

data.description: Assessments of children as early as age three and five are powerful predictors of who will go on to fail to secure good GCSE results in English language and math, a major study has revealed. Just under a half (48%) of teenagers who fail to secure standard passes in these core subjects were identified as falling behind by teachers at age 5.
data.source: Phys.org - News And Articles On Science And Technology
data.title: Half of pupils who get low grades in GCSEs already judged to be behind at age 5, study finds

data.description: Microbial populations may be small but they are surprisingly complex, making interactions with their surrounding environment difficult to study. But now, researchers from Japan have discovered that machine learning can provide the tools to do just that. In a study published this month in eLife, researchers from the University of Tsukuba have revealed that machine learning can be applied to bacterial population growth to discover how it relates to variations in their environment.
data.source: Phys.org - News And Articles On Science And Technology
data.title: Machine learning shows links between bacterial population growth and environment

data.description: EP-WXT Pathfinder, the experimental version of a module that will eventually be part of the wide-field X-ray telescope (WXT) aboard the astronomical satellite Einstein Probe (EP), released its first results Aug. 27 from an earlier test flight. These include an 800-second X-ray time-lapse photograph of a region of the Galactic center, a dense area at the core of our home galaxy, the Milky Way.
data.source: Phys.org - News And Articles On Science And Technology
data.title: EP-WXT pathfinder catches first wide-field snapshots of X-ray universe

data.description: A strong earthquake shook part of southwestern China on Monday afternoon. It wasn't immediately clear if it caused damage or injuries.
data.source: Phys.org - News And Articles On Science And Technology
data.title: Powerful quake shakes southwest China; damage not yet known

data.description: New research published in the Journal of Applied Ecology finds New Zealand's current tools and approaches are insufficient even for national predator suppression, however, researchers from the University of Auckland have identified what pest control measures are needed and where to bring mammal populations down to manageable levels.
data.source: Phys.org - News And Articles On Science And Technology
data.title: Can New Zealand coordinate national conservation efforts to control pest mammals?

data.description: The Republic of the Congo has created its first ever Marine Protected Areas (MPAs), supported by a research team including the University of Exeter and the Wildlife Conservation Society.
data.source: Phys.org - News And Articles On Science And Technology
data.title: Congo creates first Marine Protected Areas

data.description: Nuclear magnetic resonance (NMR) is an analytical tool with a wide range of applications, including the magnetic resonance imaging that is used for diagnostic purposes in medicine. However, NMR often requires powerful magnetic fields to be generated, which limits the scope of its use.
data.source: Phys.org - News And Articles On Science And Technology
data.title: Less risk, less costs: Portable spectroscopy devices could soon become real

data.description: Sick of sweltering summer heat? Well, you are in luck, because fall starts Thursday, at least according to meteorologists.
data.source: Phys.org - News And Articles On Science And Technology
data.title: Today is the first day of fall, meteorologists say. But it won't feel like it in the West

data.description: Image-based abuse, also commonly known as "revenge pornography" involves three main behaviors—non-consensually taking or creating nude or sexual images, threatening to share or distribute nude or sexual images, and non-consensually sharing or distributing nude or sexual images.
data.source: Phys.org - News And Articles On Science And Technology
data.title: Turning a blind eye to image-based abuse

data.description: Lauren Prather's new book "Monitors and Meddlers: How Foreign Actors Influence Local Trust in Elections" has been a long time in the making—a full decade, in fact.
data.source: Phys.org - News And Articles On Science And Technology
data.title: How election monitors and foreign interference in election processes can affect the public's perception of elections

data.description: A joint research team led by Dr. Jingkun Jiang from Tsinghua University and Dr. Markku Kulmala from the University of Helsinki has reported an efficient mechanism for gaseous sulfuric acid and bases to form atmospheric ultrafine particles. The findings explain the rapid formation of secondary ultrafine particles, which could further influence air quality and the climate.
data.source: Phys.org - News And Articles On Science And Technology
data.title: Hidden acid-base clusters drive rapid formation of atmospheric ultrafine particles

data.description: African countries on Friday agreed on a common push to limit global warming to 1.5 degrees Celsius—a goal that scientists fear is increasingly elusive—at upcoming UN climate talks.
data.source: Phys.org - News And Articles On Science And Technology
data.title: African countries to stand by 1.5C target at climate talkstalks

data.description: Bacteria regularly develop and deploy new antibiotics in a never-ending arms race to kill other bacterial species that compete for mutual resources. Humans have capitalized on that evolutionarily honed capability by administering antibiotics to strike at harmful bacteria that invade and infect their bodies.
data.source: Phys.org - News And Articles On Science And Technology
data.title: Experiment IDs influence of antibiotics, isolation on host bacteria

data.description: Composite particles with submicron sizes can be produced by irradiating a suspension of nanoparticles with a laser beam. Violent physical and chemical processes take place during irradiation, many of which have been poorly understood to date. Recently completed experiments, carried out at the Institute of Nuclear Physics of the Polish Academy of Sciences in Cracow, have shed new light on some of these puzzles.
data.source: Phys.org - News And Articles On Science And Technology
data.title: Laser melting: Fewer unknowns in the laser nanosynthesis of composites
